TOS_error_codes.note: If your system crashes, no error code will be displayed. In that case you will need to manually debug TOS as explained in class. Sometimes a test case will print out an error code. The detailed explanation of this code can be found on this page.

error_code.description: Memory access error: the content in a memory address is not as expected.

hints.hint: Did you peek/poke into the right memory address?
Did you peek/poke byte, word, and long properly?

error_code.description: Screen output error: incorrect characters printed on screen.

hints.hint: Did you clear the screen and place the cursor at the top left corner in clear_window()?
Did you move the cursor every time you printed a character?
Do you move the cursor to the next line when you print '\n'?
Did you use poke_b(), not poke_w() or poke_l(), to print characters onto the screen?

Did you calculate the memory address correctly? (Each visible character is represented by two bytes. The first byte is used for the character and the second byte is used for the attribute. Each line can display 80 visible characters, and there are 25 lines.)
Did you scroll the window up when the cursor reached the bottom of the window?
Did you make sure you wrap-around to the next line when you reach the right border of a window?
In printnum(), did you print '-' for negative numbers?
Did you convert the number to the correct base?
Did you remember to put padding characters when required?
When printing hexadecimal numbers, did you use upper case or lower case characters as required?

error_code.description: Screen output error: character attributes are not correct.

hints.hint: Did you use 0x0f as the default attribute?
When printing a character, did you remember to set the attribute for the character?

error_code.description: PCB array error: the number of used entries in the PCB array is not as expected.

hints.hint: In init_process(), did you mark all entries, except the one used for the boot process, as unused?
Did you change the field "used" to TRUE when initializing a PCB entry for a new process?

error_code.description: PCB array error: a created process is not in the PCB array.

hints.hint: Did you use a new (unused) PCB entry for the new process?
Did you change the field "used" to TRUE when initializing a PCB entry for the new process?

error_code.description: PCB entry error: a process's PCB entry is not initialized correctly.

hints.hint: (--- This hint applys only at stage one, before interrupts are handled ---) Did you correctly set all the following fields: magic, used, state, priority, first_port, and name?

error_code.description: Stack error: a new process's stack is not initialized correctly.

hints.hint: Did you remember to set the field "esp" when initializing the PCB entry for the new process? ("esp" should point to the last element you pushed onto the process's stack.)
Before pushing(storing) an element onto the stack, did you substract the stack pointer (the memory address where the element would be stored at) by 4?
Did you push the elements as long values?

(--- This hint applys only at stage one, before interrupts are handled ---) Did you push the following elements in the correct order onto the stack: param, self, return address(0), address of the process(func), EAX(0), ECX(0), EDX(0), EBX(0), EBP(0), ESI(0), and EDI(0)?

error_code.description: Process error: a process's state is not correct.
error_code.possible_error_source: (other functions where a process's state should be changed.)

hints.hint: When a new process is created, did you set its state to STATE_READY?

error_code.description: Ready queue error: a process is on the ready queue while it should be off the ready queue.
error_code.possible_error_source: (other functions where a process should be removed from ready queue.)

hints.hint: In init_dispatcher(), did you clean up all the ready queues and add the boot process to ready_queue[1]?
In remove_ready_queue(), did you actually remove the process from the double linked list?
Did you maintain the double linked list structure of the ready queues correctly ? (See error code 19.)
When a process's state was changed from STATE_READY to any other state, did you remove it from the ready queue?

error_code.description: Ready queue error: a process is off ready queue while it should be on ready queue.
error_code.possible_error_source: (other functions where a process should be added to the ready queue.)

hints.hint: In add_ready_queue(), did you add the process to the ready queue of the correct priority?
In create-process(), did you remember to add the new process to the ready queue?
Did you maintain the double linked list structure of the ready queues correctly? (See error code 19.)
When a process's state is changed from another state to STATE_READY, did you add it to the ready queue?

error_code.description: Ready queue error: a process is on ready queue while its state is not STATE_READY.

hints.hint: When you change a process's state from STATE_READY to any other state, did you remove it from the ready queue?
When a process is added to ready queue after being blocked, did you change its state back to STATE_READY?

error_code.description: Ready queue error: processes are in incorrect order on a ready queue. Processes on a ready queue should be in the same order as they are added to the ready queue.

hints.hint: When you add a process to a ready queue, did you add it to the end of the ready queue?
Did you maintain the double linked list structure of the ready queues correctly? (See error code 19.)

error_code.description: Ready queue error: the number of processes on the ready queues is not as expected.
error_code.possible_error_source: (other functions which add processes to or remove processes from the ready queues.

hints.hint: In init_dispatcher(), did you clean up all ready queues and add boot process to ready_queue[1]?
Did you maintain the double linked list structure of the ready queues correctly? (See error code 19.)
When required, did you remember to remove a process from or add a process to the ready queue?

error_code.description: Ready queue error: the double linked list structure of the ready queues is not maintained correclty.

hints.hint: Did you set a process's "next" and "prev" (in the PCB entry) correctly when you add it to the double linked list?
When you add a process to a ready queue, did you reset "next" and "pre" of the previous process and those of the next process?
When you remove a process from a ready queue, did you also reset "next" and "pre" of the previous process and those of the next process?
Is the double linked list Round-Robin? ("next" of the last process should point to the first process, and "pre" of the first process should point to the last process.)
Did you set ready_queue[priority] to null when the last process is removed from the ready queue of that priority?
When there is only one process on a ready queue, are its "next" and "pre" pointing to itself?

error_code.description: Process error: process's parameter is not correct.

hints.hint: (--- This hint applys only at stage one, before interrupts are handled ---) Did you push the following elements in the correct order onto the the process' stack: param, self, return address(0), address of the process(func), EAX(0), ECX(0), EDX(0), EBX(0), EBP(0), ESI(0), and EDI(0)?

error_code.description: Resign() error: context switch did not happen.

hints.hint: In create_process(), did you initialize the process's stack correctly? (See error code 12.)
(--- This hint applys only at stage one, before interrupts are handled ---) In resign(), did you first push the following registers onto the old process's stack: EAX, ECX, EDX, EBX, EBP, ESI, EDI?
In resign(), after pushing the registers onto the stack, did you set the field "esp" (in the PCB entry) of the old process? ("active_proc->esp = %ESP.)
In dispatch(), did you find the correct process to dispach? (See error code )
(--- This hint applys only at stage one, before interrupts are handled ---) In resign(), after reseting ESP, did you pop the following registers: EAX, ECX, EDX, EBX, EBP, ESI, EDI?

error_code.description: Dispatch() error: processes with lower priorities are dispatched before processes with higher priorities.
error_code.possible_error_source: (Other functions that add processes to or remove processes from ready queues)

hints.hint: In dispatch(), did you scan the ready queues?
Did you scan the ready queues in the order of priority? (Those of higher priorites should be scanned before those of lower priorities, no matter the priority of active_pro.)
Did you maintain the ready queues correclty? (See error codes 14-19.)

error_code.description: Dispatch() error: for processes of the same priority, those added to ready queue later are dispached before those added earlier.

hints.hint: In dispatch(), did you scan a ready queue forword, starting with the first process or active_proc?
In add_ready_queue(), did you add the process to the end of a ready queue?

error_code.description: Dispatch() error: processes of the same priority are dispatched incorrectly, i.e., when one process resigns, the execution is not passed to its next process. (The next process could be the active process itself or another process.)

hints.hint: In dispatch(), when there is no process of higher priority and active_proc->next is a process on the ready queue, did you dispatch it? (A common mistake is to dispatch the first process on the ready queue.)
Did you maintain the ready queue correctly? (See error codes 14-19.)

error_code.description: Dispatch() error: processes are dispatched in incorrect order. This error includes all possible situations, including those described in error code 22, 23 and 24. Please refer to the test case and screen output to find out what "incorrect order" actually is.

hints.hint: Did you maintain the double linked list structure of the ready queues correctly ? (See error code 19.)
When active_proc is not on ready queue and there is no other process of higher or the same priority as active_proc, did you scan ready queues of lower priority?
(See error code 22, 23, and 24.)

error_code.description: Dispatch() error: processes are dispatched after they are removed from ready queues.
error_code.possible_error_source: any other funtion that should remove a process from a ready queue.

hints.hint: When required, did you remember to remove a process from a ready queue? (See error code 14 and 18.)

In dispatch(), did you find the process from the ready queues? A common mistake is, when there is no process of higher priority, to dispatch active_proc->next without checking if this process is actually on the ready queue. (activer_proc-> next could be the active process itself or another process.)

error_code.description: Port error: a port is not initialized correctly.

hints.hint: When creating a new port, did you correctly initialize the port's attributes: "magic," "used," "open," and "owner?"

error_code.description: Port error: a port is not on its owner's port list.

hints.hint: When creating a new port, did you remember to add it to its owner's port list? (The head of the list is pointed by "first_port" of the process.)

error_code.description: Port error: a port is closed when it is supposed to be open.
error_code.possible_error_source: (Other functions that should open a port.)

hints.hint: In open_port(), did you change the field "open" to TRUE?
When creating a new port, did you remember to set the field "open" to TRUE?
Did you remember to call open_port() when you are supposed to?

error_code.description: Port error: a port is open when it is supposed to be close.
error_code.possible_error_source: (Other functions that should close a port.)

hints.hint: In close_port(), did you change the field "open" to FALSE?
Did you remember to call close_port() when you are supposed to?

error_code.description: IPC error: a sender did not become STATE_SEND_BLOCKED after it did a send() to a closed port or a receiver that was not ready to receive.

hints.hint: Did you check if the message could be immediatly delivered? i.e. was the receiver STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED and was the port open?
If the message could not be immediately delivered, did you change the sender to STATE_SEND_BLOCKED?

error_code.description: IPC error: a sender was not removed from the ready queue after it sent a message to a close port or a receiver that was not ready to receive.

hints.hint: Did you check if the message could be immediatly delivered? i.e. was the receiver STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED and was the port open?
If the message could not be immediately delivered, did you remove the sender from the ready queue?

error_code.description: IPC error: a sender was not blocked after it sent a message to a close port or a receiver that was not ready to receive.

hints.hint: Did you check if the message could be immediatly delivered? i.e. was the receiver STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED and was the port open?
If the message could not be immediately delivered, did you remove it from the ready queue and do a resign()?

error_code.description: IPC error: after its message was received by the receiver, a sender that was STATE_SEND_BLOCKED did not become STATE_REPLY_BLOCKED.

hints.hint: In receive(), when you found a pending sender from the blocked list, did you check if the sender is STATE_SEND_BLOCK?
If the sender was STATE_SEND_BLOCKED, did you change the sender's state to STATE_REPLY_BLOCKED?

error_code.description: IPC error: after the message was replied to by the receiver, a sender that was STATE_REPLY_BLOCKED did not become STATE_READY.

hints.hint: In reply(), did you change the sender to STATE_READY?
Did you set "sender" correctly in receive()? (So that you replyed to the correct sender in reply(). )

error_code.description: IPC error: after the message was replied to by the receiver, a sender that was STATE_REPLY_BLOCKED was not added back to the ready queue.

hints.hint: In reply(), did you add the sender back to the ready queue?
Did you set "sender" correctly in receive()? (So that you replyed to the correct sender in reply(). )

error_code.description: IPC error: the data a receiver received was not correct.

hints.hint: In send() and message(), when the message could be immediately received, i.e. the receiver was STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED and the port was open, did you set receiver's "param_proc" and "param_data" in order to pass the parameters?
In send() and message(), when the message could not be immediately received, did you set sender's "param_data" in order to pass the data?
In receive(), when the receiver is woken up from STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED, did you get the parameters from its "param_proc" and "param_data"?
In receive(), when the message was from a pending sender, did you get the data from the sender's "param_data"?

error_code.description: IPC error: the data returned from a receiver was not correct.

hints.hint: See error code 38.
In receive(), are you returning the address of the data instead of the data itself? (The return type of receive() is "void*" )

error_code.description: IPC error: a sender did not become STATE_MESSAGE_BLOCKED after it did a message() to a closed port or a receiver that was not ready to receive.

hints.hint: Did you check if the message could be immediatly delivered? i.e. was the receiver STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED and was the port open?
If the message could not be immediately delivered, did you change the sender to STATE_MESSAGE_BLOCKED?

error_code.description: IPC error: the same message was received more than once.

hints.hint: In receive(), once you received a pending message, did you remove the sender from the blocked list?

Did you maintain send blocked lists correctly? When removing a sender from the head of the list, did you set "blocked_ list_head" (of the port) to the next node? When adding a node to the end of the list, did you make sure that its "next_blocked" is pointing to NULL?

error_code.description: IPC error: after its message was received by the receiver, a sender that was STATE_MESSAGE_BLOCKED did not become STATE_READY.

hints.hint: In receive(), when you found a pending sender from a blocked list, did you check if the sender was STATE_SEND_BLOCK?
If the sender was not STATE_SEND_BLOCKED, which implied that it was STATE_MESSAGE_BLOCKED, did you change it's state to STATE_READY?

error_code.description: IPC error: after its message was received by the receiver, a sender that was STATE_MESSAGE_BLOCKED was not added back to the ready queue.

hints.hint: In receive(), when you found a pending sender from a blocked list, did you check if the sender was STATE_SEND_BLOCK?
If the sender was not STATE_SEND_BLOCKED, which implied that it was STATE_MESSAGE_BLOCKED, did you add it back to the ready queue?

error_code.description: IPC error: when there was no sender pending, a receiver was not blocked after it executed a receive().

hints.hint: Did you scan the open ports to check if there were pending senders?
When there was no sender pending, did you remove the receiver from the ready queue and do a resign()?

error_code.description: IPC error: when there was no sender pending, a receiver did not become STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED after it executed a receive().

hints.hint: Did you scan the open ports to check if there were pending senders?
When there was no sender pending, did you change the receiver to STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED?

error_code.description: IPC error: A sender was not blocked after doing a send(). When the receiver is STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED and the port is open, the sender should become STATE_REPLY_BLOCKED and be blocked; when the receiver is not STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED or the port is closed, the sender should become STATE_SEND_BLOCKED and be blocked.

hints.hint: Did you check if the receiver was ready to receive? i.e. was the receiver STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED?
Did you check if the port was open?
If the receiver was STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED and the port was open, did you change the sender to STATE_REPLY_BLOCKED, remove it from the ready queue, and did a resign()?
If the receiver is not STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED or the port is close, did you change the sender to STATE_SEND_BLOCKED, remove it from the ready queue, and did a resign()?

error_code.description: IPC error: after doing a send() to an open port of a STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED receiver, a sender did not become STATE_REPLY_BLOCKED.

hints.hint: Did you check if the message could be immediatly delivered? i.e. was the receiver STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED and was the port open?
If the message could be immediately delivered, did you change the sender to STATE_REPLY_BLOCKED?

error_code.description: IPC error: after doing a send() to an open port of a STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED receiver, a sender was not removed from the ready queue.

hints.hint: See error code 49.

error_code.description: IPC error: after a message was sent to an open port of a STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED receiver, the receiver was not added back to the ready queue.

hints.hint: Did you check if the message could be immediatly delivered? i.e. was the receiver STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED and was the port open?
If the message could be immediately delivered, did you add the receiver back to the ready queue?

error_code.description: IPC error: after a sender did a send() to an open port of a STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED receiver, the receiver did not become STATE_READY.

hints.hint: Did you check if the message could be immediatly delivered? i.e. was the receiver STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED and was the port open?
If the message could be immediately delivered, did you change the receiver's state to STATE_READY?

error_code.description: IPC error: a sender did not do a resign() at the end of message(). When receiver is STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED and the port is open, the sender calls resign() so that the receiver gets a chance to pick up the message; when the receiver is not STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED or the port is close, the sender becomes STATE_MESSAGE_BLOCKED, be removed from the ready queue, and do a resign().

IPC error: after using message() to send a message to an open port of a STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED receiver, a sender's state was not STATE_READY. When the message can be delievered immediately, the sender remains STATE_READY and on the ready queue.

IPC error: after using message() to send a message to an open port of a STATE_RECEIVE_BLOCKED receiver, a sender was taken off the ready queue. When the message can be delivered immediately, the sender should remain STATE_READY and and remain on the ready queue.
IPC error: when multiple messages were sent to a same port, they were not received in a FIFO order.

hints.hint: In receive(), did you scan a blocked list from head to tail?
In send() and message(), when the receiver was not ready to receive or the port was closed, did you add the sender to the tail of the blocked list?

error_code.description: IPC error: wrong message was received. Many possible causes, please refer to the test case to debug.
IPC error: messages were lost. The number of messages a receiver received was less than the number of messages sent to the receiver.

hints.hint: In receive(), did you scan all opened ports?
In send() and message(), when the receiver was not ready to receive or when the port was closed, did you remember to add the sender to the port's blocked list?
Did you maintain the blocked lists correctly? When you added a node to the end of the list, did you remember to set the previous node's "next_blocked" so that it pointed to the new node?

error_code.description: IPC error: messages sent to a closed port was received by the receiver. When a port is closed, all messages sent to the port become pending, and the receiver should not receive any of them until the port is re-opened.

hints.hint: In receive(), did you scan only open ports?
In message() and send(), when the port is closed, did you add the sender to the blocked list of the corret port?
Did you maintain the blocked lists corretly? When you added a node to the end of the list, did you make sure that its "next_blocked" is pointing to NULL?

error_code.description: Interrupt error: interrupts are not initialized correctly.

hints.hint: Did you initialize an IDT entry correctly in init_idt_entry()?
Did you initialize all IDT entries?
Did you call load_idt() in init_interrupts()?
Did you call re_program_interrupt_controller() in init_interrupts()?

error_code.description: Interrupt error: timer interrupt is not working properly.

hints.hint: Did you initialize interrupts correctly? (See error code 70)
Did you remember to initialize the timer isr in init_interrupts()?
Did you use "TIMER_IRQ" for timer isr?
Did you modify create_process() and resign() so that your process stacks contain EFLAGS and EIP?
Did you do a context switch in the timer isr?

error_code.description: Interrupt error: a process called wait_for_interrupt() was not removed from ready queue.

hints.hint: Did you take the process off the ready queue in wait_for_interrupt()?
Did you call resign() in wait_for_interrupt to block the process

error_code.description: Interrupt error: an interrupt did not wake up the process waiting for it.

hints.hint: In wait_for_interrupt(), did you check if there was already a process waiting for the same interrupt?
In wait_for_interrupt(), did you set interrupt_table[*_IRQ] to the process when there was no other process waiting for the same interrupt?
In isr_*, did you check if there is a process waiting for the interrupt?
In isr_*, when there is a process waiting for the interrupt, did you add the process back to ready queue?

error_code.description: Timer service error: timer service is not working properly. A process that did a send() to timer_port was not slowed down.

hints.hint: Please refer to the two funtions' pseudocode.

error_code.description: COM error: the message sent back by the loopback device is not the same as the message sent to the loopback device.

hints.hint: Please refer to lecture slides.

error_code.description: Fork() error: child process is not created correctly.
